articles.title: OCTOBER 25 AT 8 PM
articles.summary: The document outlines upcoming astronomy events and meetings for October and November, featuring a presentation on X-ray Astronomy by Bob Stern on October 25th. Other activities include introductory astronomy classes, various indoor and outdoor star parties, board meetings, and a field expedition to Henry Coe State Park.

articles.title: FIELD OF VIEW
articles.summary: The Fremont Peak Observatory Association (FPOA) celebrated the dedication of its new observatory building on Labor Day, attracting over 200 attendees. The event marked the culmination of a two-year effort, which included forming the FPOA, securing tax-free status, fundraising through a telescope sale, and constructing the facility with significant volunteer effort. This new structure will permanently house Kevin's 30-inch reflecting telescope in cooperation with the state park system.

articles.title: IN THE NEAR FUTURE
articles.summary: The FPOA observatory is nearing completion, with electrical work, interior finishing, telescope alignment, and an observing platform still needed before formal public programs begin in Spring 1987. Concurrently, the SJAA is discussing a proposal to build a portable 29-inch Dobsonian telescope for remote star parties, with an alternative suggestion for multiple 17.5-inch telescopes to maximize public access.

articles.title: A.S.P. - A.L. - W.A.A TO MEET IN SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA IN JULY 1987
articles.summary: The Astronomical Society of the Pacific, the Astronomical League, and the Western Amateur Astronomers will host their first historic joint conference from July 11-17, 1987, at Pomona College near Los Angeles. This significant event will unite nearly 20,000 astronomers and enthusiasts for a week of seminars, workshops, lectures, star parties, and other astronomy-related activities. Attendees can request a registration packet by sending a self-addressed stamped envelope to the A.S.P. in early 1987.

articles.title: ASTROPHOTO VII
articles.summary: ASTROPHOTO VII, an astrophotography conference, is scheduled for March 14, 1987, at Moorpark College in Moorpark, CA. The all-day symposium will feature prominent speakers, discussions on beginning and advanced astrophotography, information on films and techniques, an amateur competition, commercial exhibits, door prizes, and refreshments. Attendees can send a S.A.S.E. for more details.

articles.title: BOB STERN -- THE MAN WITH THE X-RAY EYES
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association is hosting astronomer Bob Stern on October 25th at 8 pm. Stern will present an informative program on X-Ray astronomy, a topic anticipated to be new and educational for many attendees.

articles.title: SURFACE FEATURES ON GANYMEDE-- THE RING NEBULA= "MY GOD! IT'S FULL OF STARS!" OR, SEE WHAT HAPPENS WHEN YOU LEAVE YOUR CAMERA T-RING AT HOME
articles.summary: This article details an exceptionally clear night of planetary observation at Fremont Peak on September 6/7, 1986, focusing on Jupiter. The observer experienced near-perfect atmospheric seeing conditions, allowing for unprecedented views of Jupiter's surface features, including 15 distinct cloud bands, festoons, and intricate details within the Great Red Spot using a Celestron 14. The report emphasizes the rare quality of the seeing and the remarkable clarity with which planetary details were resolved.

articles.title: DEEP-SKY-DIVING -- ADVENTURES IN DEEP SKY VIDEO ASTROPHOTOGRAPHY
articles.summary: The article, titled "DEEP-SKY-DIVING -- ADVENTURES IN DEEP SKY VIDEO ASTROPHOTOGRAPHY," describes an observer's detailed visual experience with a 14-inch telescope focusing on Jupiter's Galilean moons, particularly Ganymede. Despite excellent seeing conditions and meticulous optical collimation, the observer found it challenging to discern any surface details on Ganymede at 1000X magnification. The text highlights the importance and process of precise telescope collimation for optimal viewing.

articles.title: FIRST UIEWS THROUGH THE 30-INCH RING NEBULA AT 1800X
articles.summary: This article details observations made with a newly completed 30-inch Newtonian reflector under excellent seeing conditions. Kevin Medlock successfully used the telescope at an astounding 1800x to easily view the 15th magnitude central star of the Ring Nebula (M57), with some observers even spotting a fainter second star. The powerful telescope also provided exceptional views of M17 (Omega Nebula) and M13 (Hercules Globular Cluster), highlighting its impressive light-gathering capabilities despite current limitations with observing platforms.

articles.title: DEEP-SKY-DIVING -- ADVENTURES IN DEEP SKY VIDEO ASTROPHOTOGRAPHY
articles.summary: The article recounts a deep-sky video astrophotography session on August 30th where 'Mr. Video' used a video camera with large telescopes to capture celestial objects. Highlights included viewing Jupiter's moons and cloud belts with a 30-inch telescope, seeing the Saturn Nebula with an image intensifier, and capturing the Ring Nebula with a 20-inch scope. The experience astonished observers, suggesting a significant shift in astrophotography and the future demand for CCD cameras.

articles.title: A 6-INCH REFRACTOR OF EXCEPTIONAL MERIT
articles.summary: This article highlights the exceptional performance of a homemade 6-inch f/8 refractor, constructed by Randy Post, during an observing session at Fremont Peak. Despite its simple design and crude alt-azimuth mount, the telescope, featuring a Jaegers objective and surplus wide-angle eyepieces, delivered remarkably high-contrast and wide-field views of celestial objects like the Double Cluster, Andromeda Galaxy, and NGC 253, often outperforming larger instruments. The report emphasizes the instrument's smooth operation and the stunning visual experience it provided.

articles.title: AMATEURS & ASTRONOMERS OFFERED OBSERVING TIME ON HUBBLE SPACE TELESCOPE BY: STEVE PEHANICH
articles.summary: The Space Telescope Science Institute has announced a program offering amateur astronomers observing time on the Hubble Space Telescope, recognizing their significant historical and ongoing contributions to astronomical research. Dr. Riccardo Giaconni, the Institute's Director, emphasized the value of amateur insights and their consistent role in making vital discoveries and providing extensive observational data, such as tracking occultations and monitoring variable stars. This initiative aims to harness the unique perspectives of amateur astronomers for advancing scientific understanding.

articles.title: A working group has been established to work out the details of how amateurs will be granted time on the telescope.
articles.summary: A working group, led by John Chairmen, has been established to outline the process for granting amateur astronomers observing time on a telescope, likely referring to the Hubble Space Telescope (HST). The initiative anticipates a high volume of proposals from the numerous amateur astronomers in the United States, encouraging groups like SJAA to develop projects to increase their chances of securing time.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: This article provides an update on comet observations, noting the ongoing visibility of an unnamed comet and the potential late-October sighting of Halley's Comet. It primarily details Comet Wilson (1986L), describing its discovery, initial and revised magnitude predictions, and its projected visibility and brightness for Northern and Southern Hemisphere observers from late 1986 through mid-1987. Although initially dimmer than expected, Comet Wilson is predicted to brighten significantly and offer an observing window comparable to Halley's.

articles.title: WHAT GOES AROUND COMES AROUND - HALLEY'S COMET
articles.summary: The author reflects on their personal experience observing Halley's Comet, recalling their goals set a year and a half prior. They successfully achieved their objective of observing the comet on 100 different nights and indirectly met their second goal of showing it to 100 people through organized public viewing sessions. The author cherishes particular memories of these public outreach efforts.

articles.title: Comet Wilson (1986L)
articles.summary: This document provides an ephemeris for Comet Wilson (1986L) from late September to early November, listing its celestial coordinates, elongation, and estimated magnitude. It includes observational notes describing the comet as a very small, fuzzy object, and details its distances from the Sun and Earth, hinting at the possibility of a short tail. The data is intended to aid in locating and observing the comet.

articles.title: Periodic Comet Halley (1982i)
articles.summary: The article recounts two personal and poignant encounters with Comet Halley: one with an elderly former science teacher who had waited his whole life to see it, and another sharing it with his three-month-old adopted son. Following these anecdotes, the author provides practical observational data for Comet Halley, including its positions, elongations, magnitude estimates, rise times, and distances from Earth and the Sun.

articles.title: Periodic Comet Halley (1982i)
articles.summary: This document presents an ephemeris for Periodic Comet Halley (1982i) from October 22 to November 11, 1982. It details the comet's celestial coordinates (Right Ascension and Declination), elongation, apparent magnitude, and its distances from both Earth and the Sun over this period.

articles.title: BY: JIM VAN NULAND
articles.summary: This article provides a detailed schedule indicating the precise moments when Jupiter's Great Red Spot (GRS) will be directly facing Earth, making it ideally placed for observation. The tabular times are in PDT, and observers can expect to see the GRS for at least an hour before and after these moments, potentially longer under excellent seeing conditions. It serves as a practical guide for astronomers planning to view this prominent Jovian feature.

articles.title: By: JAY REYNOLDS FREEMAN
articles.summary: The article recounts a successful September 6 SJAA Star Party at Henry Coe State Park, attended by 20-30 people under excellent sky conditions. Jay Reynolds Freeman led an introductory celestial tour using an 8-inch Dobsonian telescope and binoculars, guiding participants through observations of the Moon, Venus, and numerous deep-sky objects. The report emphasizes the educational experience and the successful viewing of both common and challenging astronomical targets, such as the Andromeda Galaxy and Stefan's Quintet.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: This document features classified advertisements for used astronomy equipment, specifically three Celestron telescopes. The ads include model details, optical specifications, accessories, asking prices, and contact information for the sellers.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS
articles.summary: The SJAA holds monthly General Meetings and "Indoor Star Parties" at the Los Gatos Red Cross building, providing a friendly atmosphere for enthusiasts interested in astrophotography, deep sky observation, and telescope making. These meetings occur on the 4th Saturday of each month, starting at 8 PM, with detailed directions to the 18011 Los Gatos-Saratoga Rd location provided.

articles.title: INDOOR STAR PARTIES
articles.summary: Indoor Star Parties are informal monthly gatherings for amateur astronomers to share their interest, telescopes, and astrophotography. These events, held at the Los Gatos Red Cross Building, also include board meetings and introductory astronomy workshops. They provide a social setting for members to connect and learn.

articles.title: HENRY COE STATE PARK
articles.summary: This document provides directions to Henry Coe State Park, specifically to an observing site used by the SJAA. It includes details on accessing a locked gate with a club combination and advice for those arriving after dark, emphasizing locking the gate and scouting a site before setting up.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK STATE PARK
articles.summary: Fremont Peak State Park is a prominent astronomical observing site located 3000 ft above sea level, frequently utilized by the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) for new moon weekend activities and hosting the FPOA's public observatory. The article provides detailed driving directions to the park and lists the contact information for the SJAA's officers and board members, who are responsible for publishing their monthly newsletter, EPHEMERIS.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application form for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA). It details various membership types, including 'Membership Only', 'Membership/S&T', and 'Junior (Under 18)', along with their corresponding fees. The form collects applicant information like name, address, and telephone, and provides instructions for submission either at a meeting or by mail to the treasurer.

articles.title: Questionnaire (optional)
articles.summary: This document presents an optional questionnaire designed to gather information on individuals' astronomical interests, telescope ownership, and areas of expertise where they might assist others. It also includes postal details for a non-profit organization, SJAA EPHEMERIS, indicating it as time-sensitive news material.
